\r \r \r ','404','','publish','closed','closed','','404','','','2023-01-01 18:44:44','2023-01-01 18:44:44','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=18',0,'pagelayer-template','',0),(23,1,'2022-04-02 16:43:05','2022-04-02 16:43:05','','Blog','','publish','closed','closed','','posts','','','2023-01-02 04:12:35','2023-01-02 04:12:35','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/blog/',0,'page','',0),(24,1,'2022-04-02 16:43:05','2022-04-02 16:43:05','

We are {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} and {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} from Montréal, Canada. We speak French and English, and we are learning Croatian, Greek, German and Turkish. We started our travels in Porto Heli, Greece. Since then we have sailed over 1,200 nautical miles (2,200km) through the Peloponnese, Montenegro and Croatia. We are friendly, come say hi to us if you see our boat in the anchorage. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} is a fieldlinguist who has lived in over 30 countries and volunteers for OpenSource in her spare time and {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} used to inspect and repair electronics in a salle blanche en imagerie medical RMA team. We work in the evenings, so the best time to say hi is morning or midday when we are outside paddleboarding or doing boat projects.

Recommended Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Trello for TODOs and checklists
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back

Apps we use

  • Navionics for charts and recording traces
  • Windy for another view of weather
  • Posiedon for Greece weather

Recommended books

  • Boatowner\'s Mechanical and Electrical Manual
  • The Voyager`s Handbook

About us

We are us.

You know who we are.

Alpha Kilo Alpha Tango Oscar November

Why Akaton as a name? Well, the mot difficult part of software is naming variable… it\'s hard to charge after. After a lot of back and forth, Captain {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} being the most badass software wizard I know and Being versatile in all prosodies, (we ;) ) decided Akaton represent what we do in Life.

Let me explain. A Hackathon is about achieving the end goal in the shortest amount of time possible. We took our life the same way, let\'s just say we always have a 5y goal and we work hard against it.

  • fast to spell on the VHF
  • cvcv
  • Those who know, know
','À propos','','publish','closed','closed','','apropos','','','2023-01-02 16:48:14','2023-01-02 16:48:14','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/about/',0,'page','',0),(26,1,'2022-04-02 16:43:05','2022-04-02 16:43:05','

As a great sailor said, if the boat float it\'s a 10 -- Captain Q

Jeanneau - Sun Odyssey 42.2

Akaton is a 2000 Jeanneau Sun Odyssey 42.2. She was previously named Jakane, and Marie Dieu.

Akaton is 12.3 meters long, and 4.1 meters wide with a 2 meter draft. She has 3 cabins (she has a 4 cabin layout, with the separators removed to convert the bunks into shelves).

For more detailed info you can see the sailboat database: layout and specs

  • 440L of water or ~20-30day of careful water usage for 2 people
  • 175L of Diesel or ~80h of motor at 4N/h so ~300NM (550km)
  • 300W of Solar panel + 300w wind turbine so unlimited time sitting in a bay
  • 12v Water make that make 30l/h that allow to be remote.
  • Full sail complement with Furling main, Storm Sail, Genoa & asymmetric spinnaker.

','The Boat','','inherit','closed','closed','','26-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:16:42','2023-01-01 19:16:42','',26,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=69',0,'revision','',0),(71,1,'2023-01-01 19:28:57','2023-01-01 19:28:57','

The Beginning!

Notre roulotte qui flotte

About Us

We Start

May 1 2022

Favourite Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back to the boat

Apps we use

  • Navionics for charts and recording traces so we can retrace our back to where we wanted to anchor.
  • Windy for another view of weather
  • Posiedon for Greece weather

Contact Us

Porto Heli, Greece 2021-2022

Milna, Croatia 2022-2023

','Home','','inherit','closed','closed','','24-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:28:57','2023-01-01 19:28:57','',24,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=71',0,'revision','',0),(72,2,'2022-03-01 21:26:00','2022-03-01 21:26:00','

Where did it start?

Maybe 5-6 years ago we started to look at sailing channels, one I still remember was titled: “Do not buy a sailboat” which convinced us ironically to start the rabbit hole of boats. We went from looking at the adventure to people restoring wooden sailboats with Fiberglass repair. We were always more interested in how things can build & the process than the adventure itself. So when we started looking at the market, we were looking as much as Project to Perfect sailboat. This also creates a problem in that there is a lot to look at and it\'s really hard to compare one vs the other.

Finding a boat:

We thought the price was really expensive just before Covid, but we were up for a surprise when we saw the price go up during the pandemic 😷. We looked at a super cheap project boat on the north east atlantc coast, but this also mean all weekend doing fiberglass job in a boatyard instead of enjoying it. At this point we had 2 diverging options, go all in into a bigger project boat (hurricane damaged, badly maintained, etc…) and dump a lot of time into it, OR keep working in high paying job and just buy a well-maintained boat.

Scouting for boats into “exotics?” places.

  • Puerto Rico
  • US Virgin Islands
  • Croatia 2x
  • Florida (keys)
  • Greece
    Every occasion is good to look for what is out there and how marina works.

The patterns we found:

Boats in the USA are about 1.5x more expensive than boat in the Mediterranean.
There is a lot more boat in the Med than US/Caribbean.
Boats in the Caribbean gets cheaper around summer (June-Sept) to avoid hiding the boat for the hurricane season.
Boats in the Mediterranean are cheaper between September-December to avoid Haul-out costs & for company to rotate the stocks.

So...?

On a cold night in the hot tub in Daytona beach, the subject came back to “Oh I wonder what is out there now”, so we looked for fun. We were not expecting to find anything since it\'s supposed to be the low season for selling boats, and all the good boats that were cheap as a bargain would be already gone by October. But we found a Hanse 41 for 74k (Euro) in Greece, It was a good price since most boats we looked at were ~100-150k So even if we would give a bit of love it should still work. The same idea as our house, the foundation need to be good. So we can fix small details but any structural damage we are out (especially for the first-time owner). So for the first time, we contacted the agent and started to talk and see what was the process. We might do a whole blog about what the processes later. But basically they wanted us to inspect the boat before we even put in an offer, in so we schedule everything and because we half crazy and flexible, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} decided to be present for the inspection of the boat increase the next week. With the limited info from the agent and a few outside pictures, Crazy details oriented {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} was able to find details like the hill behind the boat to reference google picture and find where the boat was located IN GREECE!!! {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was also able to find out who owned the boat and who sold it to who without any detail from the agent… Hard to hide stuff from {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} 🙃.

The inspection

We found an inspector Walsh that is super good at inspection, if there is a defect he will find it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was there for the inspection and of course, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} also found details that Walsh missed 🤣. There were some red flags for the boat like structural and oddity so we wanted to make an offer of 61k since there were so many red flags, but the agent convinced to made at least a higher offer of 64k. They rejected it so we move along. As simple as that. But {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was in Greece now so she kept going and scouted all corners to find the “perfect boat”. We found 2 but by the time we made an offer one was gone. We looked at another one JackAnne owned by a French couple. Again {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} found where the boat was without any help from the agent. It surprised the agent again to see {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} there without any help 😂. We inspected and saw it had a few items to fix, but nothing major, so we made a cautious offer around the asking price of 74k. And… we got it. But… we could not make the inspection now since it was not ready so we had to wait 1 month before we could do it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was already there for about 1 month, so she had to exit Greece (Schengen zone) until they were ready for an inspection. We both flew back for 1 week for the inspection and all went well since {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} spotted most of the items already.

Result:

','Finding a boat','','publish','open','open','','finding-a-boat','','','2023-02-12 22:21:26','2023-02-12 22:21:26','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=72',0,'post','',0),(74,1,'2023-01-01 19:30:55','2023-01-01 19:30:55','

About US

We are us.

You know who we are.

','About','','inherit','closed','closed','','25-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:30:55','2023-01-01 19:30:55','',25,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=74',0,'revision','',0),(75,2,'2023-01-01 19:36:53','2023-01-01 19:36:53','

Finding a boat

Where did it start?

Maybe 5-6 years ago we started to look at sailing channels, one I still remember was titled: “Do not buy a sailboat”. We went from looking at the adventure to people restoring sailboats with Fiberglass repair. We were always more interested in how things can build & the process than the adventure itself. So when we started looking at the market, we were looking as much as Project to Perfect sailboat. This also creates a problem in that there is a lot to look at and it\'s really hard to compare one vs the other.

Finding a boat:

We thought the price was really expensive just before Covid we were up to a surprise when we saw the price go up during the pandemic 😷 :(. We looked at a super cheap project boat around NYC, but this also mean all weekend doing fiberglass job in a boatyard instead of enjoying it. At this point we had 2 diverging options, go all in into a bigger project boat (hurricane damaged, badly maintained, etc…) and dump a lot of time into it, OR keep working into high paying job and just buy a well maintained boat.

Scouting for boat into “exotics?” places.

  • Puerto Rico
  • US Virgin Islands
  • Croatia 2x
  • Florida (keys)
  • Greece
    Every occasion is good to look for what is out there and how marina works.

The patterns we found:
Boat in the USA are about 1.5x more expensive than boat in the Mediterranean.
There is a lot more boat in the Med than US/Caribbean.
Boat in the Caribbean gets cheaper around summer (June-Sept) to avoid hiding the boat for the hurricane season.
Boat in the Mediterranean are cheaper between September-December to avoid Haul-out cost & for company to rotate the stocks.

On a cold night in the hot tub in Daytona beach the subject came back to “Oh I wonder what is out there now”, so we looked for fun. We were not expecting to find anything since it\'s supposed to be the low season for selling boat, and all the good boat that were cheap as a bargain would be already gone by October. But we found a Hanse 41 for 74k (Euro) in Greece, It was a good price since most boat we looked at were ~100-150k So even if we would give a bit of love it should still work. The same idea as our house, the foundation need to be good. So we can fix small details but any structural damaged we are out (specially for the first time owner). So for the first time we contacted the agent and started to talk and see what was a process we might do a whole blog about what the processes later. But basically they wanted us to do the inspection of the boat before we even put an offer, in so we schedule everything and because we half crazy and flexible, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} decided to be present for the inspection of the boat increase the next week. With the limited info from the agent and a few outside picture, Crazy details oriented {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was able to find details like hill behind the boat to reference google picture and find where the boat was located IN GREECE!!! {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was also able to find who owned the boat and who sold it to who without any detail from the agent… Hard to hide stuff from {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} 🙃.

The inspection:
We found an inspector Walsh that is super good at inspection, if there is a defect he will find it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was there for the inspection and of course, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} also found details that Walsh missed 🤣. There were some red flags for the boat like structural and oddity so we wanted to make an offer of 61k since there were so many red flags, but got convinced to made a lower offer of 64k. They rejected it so we move along. But {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was in Greece now so she kept going and scouted all corner to find the “perfect boat”. We found 2 but by the time we made an offer one was gone. We looked at another one JackAnne owned by a French couple. Again {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} found where the boat was without any help from the agent. It surprised the agent again to see {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} there without any help 😂. We inspected and saw it had a few items to fix, but nothing major, so we made a cautious offer around the asking price of 74k. And… we got it. But… we could not make the inspection now since it was not ready so we had to wait 1 month before we could do it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was already there for about 1 month so she had to exit Greece (Schengen zone) until they were ready for an inspection. We both flew back for 1 week for the inspection and all went well since {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} spotted most of the item already.

','','','inherit','closed','closed','','72-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:36:53','2023-01-01 19:36:53','',72,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=75',0,'revision','',0),(76,2,'2023-01-01 19:38:06','2023-01-01 19:38:06','

Finding a boat

Where did it start?

Maybe 5-6 years ago we started to look at sailing channels, one I still remember was titled: “Do not buy a sailboat”. We went from looking at the adventure to people restoring sailboats with Fiberglass repair. We were always more interested in how things can build & the process than the adventure itself. So when we started looking at the market, we were looking as much as Project to Perfect sailboat. This also creates a problem in that there is a lot to look at and it\'s really hard to compare one vs the other.

Finding a boat:

We thought the price was really expensive just before Covid we were up to a surprise when we saw the price go up during the pandemic 😷 :(. We looked at a super cheap project boat around NYC, but this also mean all weekend doing fiberglass job in a boatyard instead of enjoying it. At this point we had 2 diverging options, go all in into a bigger project boat (hurricane damaged, badly maintained, etc…) and dump a lot of time into it, OR keep working into high paying job and just buy a well maintained boat.

Scouting for boat into “exotics?” places.

  • Puerto Rico
  • US Virgin Islands
  • Croatia 2x
  • Florida (keys)
  • Greece
    Every occasion is good to look for what is out there and how marina works.

The patterns we found:
Boat in the USA are about 1.5x more expensive than boat in the Mediterranean.
There is a lot more boat in the Med than US/Caribbean.
Boat in the Caribbean gets cheaper around summer (June-Sept) to avoid hiding the boat for the hurricane season.
Boat in the Mediterranean are cheaper between September-December to avoid Haul-out cost & for company to rotate the stocks.

On a cold night in the hot tub in Daytona beach the subject came back to “Oh I wonder what is out there now”, so we looked for fun. We were not expecting to find anything since it\'s supposed to be the low season for selling boat, and all the good boat that were cheap as a bargain would be already gone by October. But we found a Hanse 41 for 74k (Euro) in Greece, It was a good price since most boat we looked at were ~100-150k So even if we would give a bit of love it should still work. The same idea as our house, the foundation need to be good. So we can fix small details but any structural damaged we are out (specially for the first time owner). So for the first time we contacted the agent and started to talk and see what was a process we might do a whole blog about what the processes later. But basically they wanted us to do the inspection of the boat before we even put an offer, in so we schedule everything and because we half crazy and flexible, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} decided to be present for the inspection of the boat increase the next week. With the limited info from the agent and a few outside picture, Crazy details oriented {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was able to find details like hill behind the boat to reference google picture and find where the boat was located IN GREECE!!! {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was also able to find who owned the boat and who sold it to who without any detail from the agent… Hard to hide stuff from {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} 🙃.

The inspection:
We found an inspector Walsh that is super good at inspection, if there is a defect he will find it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was there for the inspection and of course, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} also found details that Walsh missed 🤣. There were some red flags for the boat like structural and oddity so we wanted to make an offer of 61k since there were so many red flags, but got convinced to made a lower offer of 64k. They rejected it so we move along. But {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was in Greece now so she kept going and scouted all corner to find the “perfect boat”. We found 2 but by the time we made an offer one was gone. We looked at another one JackAnne owned by a French couple. Again {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} found where the boat was without any help from the agent. It surprised the agent again to see {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} there without any help 😂. We inspected and saw it had a few items to fix, but nothing major, so we made a cautious offer around the asking price of 74k. And… we got it. But… we could not make the inspection now since it was not ready so we had to wait 1 month before we could do it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was already there for about 1 month so she had to exit Greece (Schengen zone) until they were ready for an inspection. We both flew back for 1 week for the inspection and all went well since {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} spotted most of the item already.

','','','inherit','closed','closed','','72-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:38:06','2023-01-01 19:38:06','',72,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=76',0,'revision','',0),(77,1,'2023-01-01 19:40:05','2023-01-01 19:40:05','

How to use this page

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the boat calendar
  3. You should see the boat calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the boat calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the boat calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring a long sleeve sunshirt, sunglasses, a hat and hiking shoes. Bring very little, we have everything you might need.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than in Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimmable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring the water is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

How long should we visit?
We are always happy to have our friends and family visit us. We recommend visiting for two weeks or longer so that you have at least three days to do nothing but get adjusted to the timezone. We recommend arriving and departing on weekdays if possible since there are more frequent ferries and busses so it is easier to arrive at the boat/airport. Sundays are a day of rest in Europe, don\'t expect to travel or go to stores on Sundays. We have three cabins, we can sleep 4 adults and 3 kids comfortably. We have found that Jet lag will make you dehydrated, drowsy and nauseous so we won\'t plan to do activities when you arrive. We have paddleboards, snorkels, fishing rods, a spear gun, and many other activities you can do when you visit. If you are able to work remotely and can visit for longer, we can anchor near a village where we can go to cafes and explore life on land as well.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Schengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Schengen area to buy more time in the Schengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','publish','closed','closed','','calendrier','','','2023-01-02 16:50:35','2023-01-02 16:50:35','',25,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?page_id=77',0,'page','',0),(78,1,'2023-01-01 19:40:05','2023-01-01 19:40:05',' ','','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:40:05','2023-01-01 19:40:05','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=78',0,'revision','',0),(79,1,'2023-01-01 19:41:23','2023-01-01 19:41:23',' ','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:41:23','2023-01-01 19:41:23','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=79',0,'revision','',0),(80,1,'2023-01-01 19:41:48','2023-01-01 19:41:48',' ','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 19:41:48','2023-01-01 19:41:48','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=80',0,'revision','',0),(81,1,'2023-01-01 19:45:53','2023-01-01 19:45:53','

As a great sailor said, if the boat float it\'s a 10 -- Captain Q

SV.Akaton:

Why Akaton as a name? Well, the mot difficult part of software is naming variable… it\'s hard to charge after. After a lot of back and forth, Captain {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} being the most badass software wizard I know and Being versatile in all tongue twisting prosody, (we ;) decided Akaton represent what we do in Life.

Let me explain.
A Hackaton in software is about achieving the end goal in the shortest amount of time possible. We took our life the same way, let\'s just say we always have a 5y goal and we work hard against it.

cvcv
mvp
fast

Those who know, know.

The Beginning!

Notre roulotte qui flotte

About Us

We Start

May 1 2022

Favourite Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back to the boat

Apps we use

  • Navionics for charts and recording traces so we can retrace our back to where we wanted to anchor.
  • Windy for another view of weather
  • Posiedon for Greece weather

Contact Us

Porto Heli, Greece 2021-2022

Milna, Croatia 2022-2023

Why Akaton as a name? Well, the mot difficult part of software is naming variable… it\'s hard to charge after. After a lot of back and forth, Captain {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} being the most badass software wizard I know and Being versatile in all tongue twisting prosody, (we ;) decided Akaton represent what we do in Life.

Let me explain.
A Hackaton in software is about achieving the end goal in the shortest amount of time possible. We took our life the same way, let\'s just say we always have a 5y goal and we work hard against it.

mvp
fast

Those who know, know.

','Le Bateau','','inherit','closed','closed','','26-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 20:52:13','2023-01-01 20:52:13','',26,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=93',0,'revision','',0),(96,1,'2023-01-01 20:58:21','2023-01-01 20:58:21','

As a great sailor said, if the boat float it\'s a 10 -- Captain Q

SV.Akaton:

Jeanneau - Sun Odyssey 42.2

Akaton is a 2000 Jeanneau Sun Odyssey 42.2. She was previously named Jakane, and Marie Dieu.

Akaton is 12.3 meters long, and 4.1 meters wide with a 2 meter draft. She has 3 cabins, (she has a 4 cabin layout, with the seperators removed to convert the bunks into shelves). We are always happy to have our friends and family visit us, preferably for two weeks or longer.

For more info you can use the Sailboat data: layout and specs

','À propos','','inherit','closed','closed','','25-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 21:07:03','2023-01-01 21:07:03','',25,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=103',0,'revision','',0),(104,2,'2023-01-01 21:09:29','2023-01-01 21:09:29','

Where did it start?

Maybe 5-6 years ago we started to look at sailing channels, one I still remember was titled: “Do not buy a sailboat”. We went from looking at the adventure to people restoring sailboats with Fiberglass repair. We were always more interested in how things can build & the process than the adventure itself. So when we started looking at the market, we were looking as much as Project to Perfect sailboat. This also creates a problem in that there is a lot to look at and it\'s really hard to compare one vs the other.

Finding a boat:

We thought the price was really expensive just before Covid, but we were up for a surprise when we saw the price go up during the pandemic 😷. We looked at a super cheap project boat around NYC, but this also mean all weekend doing fiberglass job in a boatyard instead of enjoying it. At this point we had 2 diverging options, go all in into a bigger project boat (hurricane damaged, badly maintained, etc…) and dump a lot of time into it, OR keep working into high paying job and just buy a well maintained boat.

Scouting for boat into “exotics?” places.

  • Puerto Rico
  • US Virgin Islands
  • Croatia 2x
  • Florida (keys)
  • Greece
    Every occasion is good to look for what is out there and how marina works.

The patterns we found:

Boat in the USA are about 1.5x more expensive than boat in the Mediterranean.
There is a lot more boat in the Med than US/Caribbean.
Boat in the Caribbean gets cheaper around summer (June-Sept) to avoid hiding the boat for the hurricane season.
Boat in the Mediterranean are cheaper between September-December to avoid Haul-out cost & for company to rotate the stocks.

So...?

On a cold night in the hot tub in Daytona beach the subject came back to “Oh I wonder what is out there now”, so we looked for fun. We were not expecting to find anything since it\'s supposed to be the low season for selling boat, and all the good boat that were cheap as a bargain would be already gone by October. But we found a Hanse 41 for 74k (Euro) in Greece, It was a good price since most boat we looked at were ~100-150k So even if we would give a bit of love it should still work. The same idea as our house, the foundation need to be good. So we can fix small details but any structural damaged we are out (specially for the first time owner). So for the first time we contacted the agent and started to talk and see what was a process we might do a whole blog about what the processes later. But basically they wanted us to do the inspection of the boat before we even put an offer, in so we schedule everything and because we half crazy and flexible, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} decided to be present for the inspection of the boat increase the next week. With the limited info from the agent and a few outside picture, Crazy details oriented {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was able to find details like hill behind the boat to reference google picture and find where the boat was located IN GREECE!!! {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was also able to find who owned the boat and who sold it to who without any detail from the agent… Hard to hide stuff from {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} 🙃.

The inspection

We found an inspector Walsh that is super good at inspection, if there is a defect he will find it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was there for the inspection and of course, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} also found details that Walsh missed 🤣. There were some red flags for the boat like structural and oddity so we wanted to make an offer of 61k since there were so many red flags, but got convinced to made a lower offer of 64k. They rejected it so we move along. But {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was in Greece now so she kept going and scouted all corner to find the “perfect boat”. We found 2 but by the time we made an offer one was gone. We looked at another one JackAnne owned by a French couple. Again {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} found where the boat was without any help from the agent. It surprised the agent again to see {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} there without any help 😂. We inspected and saw it had a few items to fix, but nothing major, so we made a cautious offer around the asking price of 74k. And… we got it. But… we could not make the inspection now since it was not ready so we had to wait 1 month before we could do it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was already there for about 1 month so she had to exit Greece (Schengen zone) until they were ready for an inspection. We both flew back for 1 week for the inspection and all went well since {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} spotted most of the item already.

Result:

How to use this page

  1. Login to your Gmail
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.
','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 21:15:53','2023-01-01 21:15:53','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=106',0,'revision','',0),(107,2,'2023-01-01 21:26:19','2023-01-01 21:26:19','

Where did it start?

Maybe 5-6 years ago we started to look at sailing channels, one I still remember was titled: “Do not buy a sailboat”. We went from looking at the adventure to people restoring sailboats with Fiberglass repair. We were always more interested in how things can build & the process than the adventure itself. So when we started looking at the market, we were looking as much as Project to Perfect sailboat. This also creates a problem in that there is a lot to look at and it\'s really hard to compare one vs the other.

Finding a boat:

We thought the price was really expensive just before Covid, but we were up for a surprise when we saw the price go up during the pandemic 😷. We looked at a super cheap project boat around NYC, but this also mean all weekend doing fiberglass job in a boatyard instead of enjoying it. At this point we had 2 diverging options, go all in into a bigger project boat (hurricane damaged, badly maintained, etc…) and dump a lot of time into it, OR keep working in high paying job and just buy a well-maintained boat.

Scouting for boats into “exotics?” places.

  • Puerto Rico
  • US Virgin Islands
  • Croatia 2x
  • Florida (keys)
  • Greece
    Every occasion is good to look for what is out there and how marina works.

The patterns we found:

Boats in the USA are about 1.5x more expensive than boat in the Mediterranean.
There is a lot more boat in the Med than US/Caribbean.
Boats in the Caribbean gets cheaper around summer (June-Sept) to avoid hiding the boat for the hurricane season.
Boats in the Mediterranean are cheaper between September-December to avoid Haul-out costs & for company to rotate the stocks.

So...?

On a cold night in the hot tub in Daytona beach, the subject came back to “Oh I wonder what is out there now”, so we looked for fun. We were not expecting to find anything since it\'s supposed to be the low season for selling boats, and all the good boats that were cheap as a bargain would be already gone by October. But we found a Hanse 41 for 74k (Euro) in Greece, It was a good price since most boats we looked at were ~100-150k So even if we would give a bit of love it should still work. The same idea as our house, the foundation need to be good. So we can fix small details but any structural damage we are out (especially for the first-time owner). So for the first time, we contacted the agent and started to talk and see what was the process. We might do a whole blog about what the processes later. But basically they wanted us to inspect the boat before we even put in an offer, in so we schedule everything and because we half crazy and flexible, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} decided to be present for the inspection of the boat increase the next week. With the limited info from the agent and a few outside pictures, Crazy details oriented {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was able to find details like the hill behind the boat to reference google picture and find where the boat was located IN GREECE!!! {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was also able to find out who owned the boat and who sold it to who without any detail from the agent… Hard to hide stuff from {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} 🙃.

The inspection

We found an inspector Walsh that is super good at inspection, if there is a defect he will find it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was there for the inspection and of course, {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} also found details that Walsh missed 🤣. There were some red flags for the boat like structural and oddity so we wanted to make an offer of 61k since there were so many red flags, but the agent convinced to made at least a higher offer of 64k. They rejected it so we move along. As simple as that. But {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was in Greece now so she kept going and scouted all corners to find the “perfect boat”. We found 2 but by the time we made an offer one was gone. We looked at another one JackAnne owned by a French couple. Again {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} found where the boat was without any help from the agent. It surprised the agent again to see {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} there without any help 😂. We inspected and saw it had a few items to fix, but nothing major, so we made a cautious offer around the asking price of 74k. And… we got it. But… we could not make the inspection now since it was not ready so we had to wait 1 month before we could do it. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} was already there for about 1 month, so she had to exit Greece (Schengen zone) until they were ready for an inspection. We both flew back for 1 week for the inspection and all went well since {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} spotted most of the items already.

Result:

','Finding a boat','','inherit','closed','closed','','72-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 21:26:19','2023-01-01 21:26:19','',72,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=107',0,'revision','',0),(108,1,'2023-01-01 21:26:58','2023-01-01 21:26:58','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.
','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 21:26:58','2023-01-01 21:26:58','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=108',0,'revision','',0),(110,1,'2023-01-01 23:19:34','2023-01-01 23:19:34','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need (including sunscreen and 6 extra hats).

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected, we will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes!

  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need (including sunscreen and 6 extra hats).

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes!

What if i have never lived on a boat?
You can watch this video about boat life.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need (including sunscreen and 6 extra hats).

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes!

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch this video about boat life.

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need (including sunscreen and 6 extra hats).

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes!

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch this video about boat life, it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different on a boat.


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 23:41:54','2023-01-01 23:41:54','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=116',0,'revision','',0),(117,1,'2023-01-01 23:49:14','2023-01-01 23:49:14','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need (including sunscreen and 6 extra hats).

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes!

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-01 23:49:14','2023-01-01 23:49:14','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=117',0,'revision','',0),(118,1,'2023-01-02 00:14:24','2023-01-02 00:14:24','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need. Do bring long sleeve sunshirts, sunglasses and a hat.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring it is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didnt expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will achor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:14:24','2023-01-02 00:14:24','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=118',0,'revision','',0),(119,1,'2023-01-02 00:16:43','2023-01-02 00:16:43','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the calendar
  3. You should see the calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need. Do bring long sleeve sunshirts, sunglasses and a hat.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring it is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:16:43','2023-01-02 00:16:43','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=119',0,'revision','',0),(120,1,'2023-01-02 00:19:30','2023-01-02 00:19:30','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the boat calendar
  3. You should see the boat calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the boat calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the boat calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need. Do bring long sleeve sunshirts, sunglasses and a hat.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring it is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:19:30','2023-01-02 00:19:30','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=120',0,'revision','',0),(121,1,'2023-01-02 00:22:04','2023-01-02 00:22:04','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the boat calendar
  3. You should see the boat calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the boat calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the boat calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring very little, we have everything you might need. Do bring long sleeve sunshirts, sunglasses and a hat.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring the water is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:22:04','2023-01-02 00:22:04','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=121',0,'revision','',0),(122,1,'2023-01-02 00:25:17','2023-01-02 00:25:17','

Favourite Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back to the boat

Apps we use

  • Navionics for charts and recording traces so we can retrace our back to where we wanted to anchor.
  • Windy for another view of weather
  • Posiedon for Greece weather

Contact Us

Porto Heli, Greece 2021-2022

Milna, Croatia 2022-2023

','Accueil','','inherit','closed','closed','','24-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:25:17','2023-01-02 00:25:17','',24,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=122',0,'revision','',0),(124,1,'2023-01-02 00:26:46','2023-01-02 00:26:46','

  • Trello for TODOs and checklists
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings

00:30:24','','akaton','','inherit','open','closed','','akaton-2','','','2023-01-02 00:30:24','2023-01-02 00:30:24','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/akaton-1.gif',0,'attachment','image/gif',0),(129,1,'2023-01-02 00:31:56','2023-01-02 00:31:56','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/cropped-akaton-1.gif',0,'attachment','image/gif',0),(130,1,'2023-01-02 00:35:40','2023-01-02 00:35:40','','akaton-logo','','inherit','open','closed','','akaton-logo','','','2023-01-02 00:35:40','2023-01-02 00:35:40','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/akaton-logo.png',0,'attachment','image/png',0),(131,1,'2023-01-02 00:35:56','2023-01-02 00:35:56','https://akaton.ca/blog/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/cropped-akaton-logo.png','cropped-akaton-logo.png','','inherit','open','closed','','cropped-akaton-logo-png','','','2023-01-02 00:35:56','2023-01-02 00:35:56','',0,'https://akaton.ca/blog/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/cropped-akaton-logo.png',0,'attachment','image/png',0),(133,1,'2023-01-02 00:38:59','2023-01-02 00:38:59','

As a great sailor said, if the boat float it\'s a 10 -- Captain Q

Jeanneau - Sun Odyssey 42.2

Akaton is a 2000 Jeanneau Sun Odyssey 42.2. She was previously named Jakane, and Marie Dieu.

Akaton is 12.3 meters long, and 4.1 meters wide with a 2 meter draft. She has 3 cabins (she has a 4 cabin layout, with the seperators removed to convert the bunks into shelves).

For more detailed info you can see the sailboat database: layout and specs

','Le Bateau','','inherit','closed','closed','','26-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:38:59','2023-01-02 00:38:59','',26,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=133',0,'revision','',0),(135,1,'2023-01-02 00:52:14','2023-01-02 00:52:14','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the boat calendar
  3. You should see the boat calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the boat calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the boat calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring a long sleeve sunshirt, sunglasses, a hat and hiking shoes. Bring very little, we have everything you might need.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring the water is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

How long should we visit?
We are always happy to have our friends and family visit us. We reccommend visiting for two weeks or longer so that you have at least three days to do nothing but get adjusted to the timezone. We have found that Jet lag will make you dehydrated, drowsy and nauseous so we won\'t plan to do activities when you arrive. We have paddleboards, snorkels, fishing rods, a spear gun, and many other activites you can do when you visit. If you visit for longer, we can anchor near a village where you can explore life on land as well. We recommend arriving and departing on weekdays if posisble since there are more frequent ferries and busses so it is easier to arrive at the boat/airport. Sundays are a day of rest in Europe, don\'t dont expect to travel or go to stores on Sundays.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:52:14','2023-01-02 00:52:14','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=135',0,'revision','',0),(137,1,'2023-01-02 00:58:29','2023-01-02 00:58:29','

How to use this page:

  1. Login to your Gmail in your browser
  2. Refresh this page if you cannot see the boat calendar
  3. You should see the boat calendar if we know your Gmail
  4. Create an event on your Gmail calendar
  5. Invite the boat calendar 44mo93jo7hfhl40en5q9187hq8@group.calendar.google.com to your event
  6. The boat will automatically accept your event
  7. You can now view your event in the boat calendar
  8. Others who are able to see the boat calendar (our friends and family) can now see when you are coming to visit us so they can plan when they want to visit if we have space.

FAQ

What should we bring?
Bring a long sleeve sunshirt, sunglasses, a hat and hiking shoes. Bring very little, we have everything you might need.

When can we visit?
Our boat is currently at a marina until April 30. This is a great time to visit us because you can walk off the boat and into the village. This summer we will be in Croatia or Montenegro. The spring in Milna starts much earlier than Montreal. The air temperature is comfortable to sit outside (above 16 degrees) from April until November. Water temperature is swimable (above 18 degrees) from May until December. In the spring the water is not very warm, similar to a lake in Quebec in June, we have 3 shortie wetsuits you can use.

How long should we visit?
We are always happy to have our friends and family visit us. We reccommend visiting for two weeks or longer so that you have at least three days to do nothing but get adjusted to the timezone. We recommend arriving and departing on weekdays if posisble since there are more frequent ferries and busses so it is easier to arrive at the boat/airport. Sundays are a day of rest in Europe, don\'t dont expect to travel or go to stores on Sundays. We have three cabins, we can sleep 4 adults and 3 kids comfortably. We have found that Jet lag will make you dehydrated, drowsy and nauseous so we won\'t plan to do activities when you arrive. We have paddleboards, snorkels, fishing rods, a spear gun, and many other activites you can do when you visit. If you are able to work remotely and can visit for longer, we can anchor near a village where we can go to cafes and explore life on land as well.

Do you need boatsitters in May or July?
Yes! This year Croatia joined the Shengen zone, which we didn\'t expect to happen. If we do not get a visa to stay longer in Croatia, we might need boat sitters to help watch the boat while we leave the Shengen area to buy more time in the Shengen time limits. As Canadians, we can only be in Croatia or Greece for a total of 90 days out of 180 days. So if you are free to boatsit this spring/summer, let us know!

Can I boatsit if I don\'t know how to drive a boat?
Yes! We will anchor the boat somewhere it is protected. We will show you how to drive the boat and let you practice lifting the anchor and setting the anchor, but you won\'t need to move it if you don\'t know how. You can get around and go fishing using the digny (our \"car\" that has a small outboard engine).

What if I have never lived on a boat?
Think of boat living as camping. We have limited water, electricity, propane and internet. You can watch The O\'Kelly\'s video about being a guest on a boat; it has lots of tips and explanations of why some habits are different when visiting a boat vs visiting a house.

We LOVE sharing the cruising lifestyle with guests and crew aboard Clarity. But for folks who’ve never lived on a boat before, there’s some adjusting required. Limited water and power, food and internet are all issues visitors need to be aware of....important toilet concerns as well. We got a chuckle out of making this one! Enjoy! - The O\'Kelly\'s


','Calendrier','','inherit','closed','closed','','77-revision-v1','','','2023-01-02 00:58:29','2023-01-02 00:58:29','',77,'https://akaton.ca/blog/?p=137',0,'revision','',0),(139,1,'2023-01-02 01:15:30','2023-01-02 01:15:30','

We are {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} and {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} from Montréal, Canada. We speak French and English, and we are learning Croatian, Greek, German and Turkish. We started our travels in Porto Heli, Greece. Since then we have sailed over 2,000 nautical miles to Croatia. We are friendly, come say hi to us if you see our boat in the anchorage. We work in the evenings, so the best time to say hi is morning or midday when we are outside paddleboarding or doing boat projects.

Here is a list of apps/boatyards that we recommend.

Contact Us

Porto Heli, Greece 2021-2022

Milna, Croatia 2022-2023

Favourite Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Trello for TODOs and checklists
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back to the boat

Apps we use

  • Navionics for charts and recording traces so we can retrace our back to where we wanted to anchor.
  • Windy for another view of weather
  • Posiedon for Greece weather

We are {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} and {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} from Montréal, Canada. We speak French and English, and we are learning Croatian, Greek, German and Turkish. We started our travels in Porto Heli, Greece. Since then we have sailed over 2,000 nautical miles to Croatia. We are friendly, come say hi to us if you see our boat in the anchorage. {{AUTHOR_CESINE}} is a fieldlinguist who has lived in over 30 countries and volunteers for OpenSource in her spare time and {{AUTHOR_MATMATH}} used to inspect and repair electronics in a salle blanche en imagerie medical RMA team. We work in the evenings, so the best time to say hi is morning or midday when we are outside paddleboarding or doing boat projects.

Here is a list of boatyards/tavernas/apps/books that we recommend.

Recommended places

Porto Heli, Greece 2021-2022

Milna, Croatia 2022-2023

Recommended Apps

  • Navily for finding achorages
  • Trello for TODOs and checklists
  • Meteo.hr for Croatia warnings
  • Predictwind for weather models and AIS
  • Komoot for finding trails and recording hikes so we can find our way back
